data: Comprehensive collection of archaeological material discovered in the province of Ragusa, with a particular focus on the sites of Kaukana, Kamarina, Castiglione and Monte Casasia

"Magia" rurale siciliana: Iscrizioni di Noto e Modica
G. Bevilacqua e S. Giannobile, «“Magia” rurale siciliana: Iscrizioni di Noto e Modica», Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik 133 (2000): 135–46

20 lines of text on side (a), filling the face, some lines spearated by horizontal lines; 5 lines of text occupying the top part of side (b), with a large cross below, the remainder of the face blank.

Alpha tending to cursive (crossbar descending to lower left corner); eta variously standard or cursive (as a reversed N); nu is consistently reversed; theta, circle open above and blelow with cross bar overextended; kappa, upper bar joins lower left, lower bar attached to the upper bar; mu sometimes cursive; epsilon lunate; simga lunate; omega uncial.
Bevilacqua and Giannobile, 2000, "Magia" rurale siciliana: Iscrizioni di Noto e Modica

Contract for the sale of a house

The lines of text begin at the left edge of the sheet and run across to the right edge without margins. Although the original upper edge of the tablet is lost, the beginning of the text is likely preserved; it is unclear what the top margin was. The bottom margin is approximately as tall as is the text itself, i.e. the text ends around the midpoint of the sheet as currently preserved. The first four lines fill the width of the sheet and when the line ends in the middle of a word either the final letters are squeezed in (L.1) or the word is interrupted (L.3).
Composite photo of the inscribed surface, R. Souza, courtesy Museo Regionale Interdisciplinare di Ragusa

Game, 2009, Actes de vente dans le monde grec. Témoignages épigraphiques des ventes immobilières
Souza, 2016, Hellenistic Sicilian real estate contracts inscribed on lead tablets: new readings and implications for the economic independence of women

Contract for the sale of land

The lines of text begin at the left edge of the sheet (a margin of ca. 1-2 mm) and run across to the right edge leaving a right margin as narrow as ca. 1-2 mm (L.6) or as wide as ca. 7 mm (LL. 5, 9, 11): an effort was made to avoid ending a line in the middle of a word but this has happened at least between L. 1 and L. 2, and again between L. 8 and L. 9. Top margin ca. 1-2 mm; bottom margin unknown (support is broken along the entire bottom edge).
Manganaro, 1977, Tavolette di piombo inscritte della Sicilia greca

The left margin is not preserved but the first letters of most lines are preserved; the damage to the top has destroyed some of the text of L.1, and the ancient folds have damaged some of the text body. The right margin is entirely preserved and the bottom margin partially preserved.

Only the right margin of the text is preserved; the last preserved line of text may well be the final line of the original due to the lack of visible letters below it and the fact that the line runs closest to the right edge of the lamina (perhaps in an effort to avoid running onto a new line); the full bottom margin is not preserved. Top and left margins are unknown. No word breaks at line ends.

Contract for the sale of a house and related structures

The top of the sheet is damaged and the first line of text is not well preserved, but does appear to be the first line of the document. The right margin is entirely preserved. The bottom of the sheet is damaged but the final preserved line of text does appear to be the last line of the document. The left margin is unknown, and it is an open question how much text is lost on the left side (see below in commentary). The text wraps and several words are continued fron one line onto the next, breaking roughly between syllables (Lines 4, 5).
Souza, 2022, More new readings of Hellenistic Sicilian real estate contracts involving women
